author: Rebecca Buechel

comments.message: Hi Rebecca, very relevant idea. We'd love to see a prototype of an element of this redesigned experience in the context of West Africa. Here's some tips to get you started - http://ideo.pn/pr0t0type. Another thought - can you use the toys to deliver healthcare or prevent illness is anyway? We're excited to see this idea develop!
Hi Deborah, will get on to it over the next few days asap~☼
Hi Rebbeca, great Skype today> looking forward to whipping up some stuff together, love your ides on ways to humanize what must be a terrible experience for children.

description:
TOYS: link to one center's guidelines for toys for sick kids (for ebola, the toys would need to be discarded & replaced with a new item upon discharge)~
http://www.sickkids.ca/ways-to-give/gifts-in-kind/donation-guidelines/index.html

>>>> knitting clubs could knit & donate comfort toys in duplicate for during illness & upon discharge ?

MUSIC: could soothing (culturally appropriate) music be played certain hours of the day in children's zones ?
summary: COMFORT THE CHILDREN MORE: TOYS/MUSIC/HUMAN FACE~Building on A Pi's ideas of child-adapted care, this point seems necessary for avoiding huge emotional scars for the survivors and for providing comfort to the desperately ill.Here are some visuals/links to build on this idea of what more cheerful PPE might look like as well as notions of HUMANIZING HEALTHCARE.Of course, locals (psychologists, educators) would need to give input on to CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE solutions
title: ADDING A DOSE OF CHILD-ORIENTED HEALTHCARE FOR CHILDREN SUFFERERS OF EBOLA
